choices.text: Marfan syndrome and Collagen
Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Collagen
Marfan syndrome and Fibrillin
Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Fibrillin

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his recurring joint pain and backache. She describes her son's history of hypermobility and frequent dislocations, specifically mentioning his shoulders and knees. Additionally, she notes that there is a history of heart problems on the paternal side of the family. Upon examination, the pediatrician observes an eye finding consistent with the condition suspected based on the systemic features reported. What is the likely diagnosis based on these clinical features, and what protein is defective in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marfan syndrome and Fibrillin

 

Option C.

 

The clinical features and the image of the ectopia lentis of supero temporal aspect is seen in case of Marfan syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is due to the defect in the Fibrillin protein and is autosomal dominant in nature:

 

The clinical features are:

  • Skeletal system: long limbs and fingers, a tall stature, and a thin body build. scoliosis, pectus excavatum or pectus carinatum.
  • Cardiovascular system: including aortic aneurysm, mitral valve prolapse and arrhythmias.
  • Ocular system: lens dislocation, myopia , and glaucoma .
  • Other features: affect the lungs, causing spontaneous pneumothorax .

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Marfan syndrome is due to defect in the fibrillin not the Collagen.

 

Option B. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Collagen - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders often related to defects in collagen; however, the eye finding described is not typically associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

 

Option D. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Fibrillin - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is primarily associated with collagen defects, not fibrillin.

 

Educational objective:

 

Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by hypermobility, frequent dislocations, and cardiovascular complications, such as aortic root dilatation. The eye finding often associated with Marfan syndrome is lens subluxation. The defective protein in Marfan syndrome is fibrillin-1, which is crucial for the integrity and function of connective tissue throughout the body.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 618-619 and 644-645.

choices.text: Treacher Collins Syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with a history of multiple craniofacial anomalies, including downward slanting eyes, and small jaw. The mother informs that the child had recurrent middle ear infections and has a history of hearing loss. Examination reveals a high-arched palate and respiratory difficulty due to upper airway obstruction. Imaging studies demonstrate hypoplasia of mandible with malocclusion and absence of the zygomatic arch. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features, radiological findings and the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treacher Collins Syndrome

 

Option A.

 

Treacher Collins Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting the development of the face.

 

  • Clinical features include Hypoplasia of Mandible and zygomatic arches, downward slanting eyes, cleft palate, respiratory difficulties, and hearing loss.
  • Other features include eyelid colobomas, eyelash abnormalities, and dental abnormalities.
  • Severity varies widely and treatment typically involves a multidisciplinary approach.
  • Associated congenital heart diseases are VSD, ASD, PDA

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Down Syndrome: Characterized by intellectual disability, distinct facial features (flat facial profile, slanted eyes, small ears), and other systemic manifestations. The specific craniofacial and radiological findings described do not typically align with Down Syndrome.

 

Option C. Seckel Syndrome: Known for primordial dwarfism, microcephaly, and a "bird-like" face, which does not specifically include the craniofacial anomalies or hearing issues described in the question.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome: Affects females and involves a missing or partially missing X chromosome, leading to short stature, gonadal dysgenesis, and other physical abnormalities, but not typically the craniofacial anomalies described for TCS.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 7613

questions.text: During a routine OPD session on Holi, a police officer brings in an unidentified child for age verification. To determine the child's age, you order a wrist X-ray. Upon reviewing the X-ray, you identify the age of the child to be approximately 2 months. Which of the following carpal bones did you primarily rely on to estimate the age of the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Capitate

 

Option B.

 

The fist carpel bone to ossify is the capitate which is within the first 3 months of life.

The sequence of ossification of carpal bones, as shows in the image –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scaphoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age.

 

Option C. Lunate will ossify by 2-4 years of age

 

Option D. Trapezoid will ossify by 4-6 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Although there is great individual variability, approximate ossification times are as follows:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1127

choices.text: Fragile x syndrome

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is being evaluated for short stature. During the evaluation, several distinct physical features are noted: a webbed neck, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, cubitus valgus, pectus carinatum superiorly, and a shield-like chest. An echocardiogram reveals cardiovascular abnormalities. Interestingly, similar clinical features are observed in her brother. What is the most probable diagnosis considering the clinical features and the fact that both siblings are affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Noonan syndrome

 

Option C.

 

Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition, seen both in males and females.

Present with same features of turner syndrome.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Short stature
  • Tall forehead
  • Shield chest
  • Webbed neck
  • Wide spread nipples
  • Pectus carinatum superiorly and
  • Cubitus valgus

 

Associated anomalies:

 

  • CVS: Pulmonary valve stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, ASD, VSD.
  • Gonads: male has small penis and cryptorchidism, whereas females are normal and fertile.
  • Bleeding disorders; leukemia.

 

Diagnosis:

 

USG of kidney is done to screen abnormalities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Primarily affects females and is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome. The features described fit Turner syndrome, but its occurrence in a male sibling (as in the brother mentioned) rules out this condition.

 

Option B. Klinefelter syndrome: Affects males and is characterized by an extra X chromosome (47, XXY). The clinical features mentioned do not align with Klinefelter syndrome, and it would not explain the sister's presentation.

 

Option D. Fragile X syndrome: Primarily associated with intellectual disability (low IQ), behavioural challenges, and certain physical traits, but not typically presenting with the cardiovascular and skeletal features described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by Noonan facies (hypertelorism, ptosis, short neck, low-set ears), short stature, congenital heart disease, and multiple skeletal and hematologic abnormalities.

 

Noonan syndrome can affect both males and females, which is consistent with the brother also exhibiting similar features.

 

It is primarily an autosomal dominant disorder composed of multiple genetic types. Heterozygous mutations in PTPN11 cause about 50% of Noonan cases. Other cases are caused by mutations in other RAS pathway associated genes such as KRAS, SOS1 , and NRAS. Autosomal recessive forms have also been identified due to mutations of SHOC2 or CBL.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716

questions.text: A mother from a rural area brings her 4-day-old baby to the clinic for vaccination. As the attending physician, you notice abnormalities in the child's appearance as depicted in the provided image, prompting a thorough examination. The neonate exhibits overlapping fingers, an elongated occiput, curved feet, hypoplastic nails, and cleft lip and palate. Given these findings, you suspect a chromosomal anomaly and recommend an echocardiography, which reveals a ventricular septal defect. Based on the neonate's history, clinical presentation and echo findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Edward syndrome

 

Option B.

 

Trisomy 18, it is second most common trisomy (first is down syndrome trisomy 21)

 

Clinical features:

  • Limited hip abduction
  • Clinodactyly with overlapping fingers; index over 3rd ,5th over 4th.
  • Rocker bottom feet.
  • Small and premature appearance.
  • Tight palpebral fissure
  • Prominent occiput.
  • Cleft lip palate
  • Congenital heart disease (VSD>PDA>ASD).
  • Short sternum and small nipple.

 

 

Rocker bottom feet.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patau syndrome: Also known as trisomy 13, this condition presents with severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities, including polydactyly, cleft lip and palate, and microphthalmia, but the specific combination of features mentioned does not align as closely with Patau syndrome as with Edward syndrome.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: This condition is characterized by congenital heart defects, specific facial features, and immune system deficiencies, resulting from a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2. The described features do not match the typical presentation of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. Williams syndrome: Known for distinctive facial features, cardiovascular disease (especially supravalvular aortic stenosis), and a unique cognitive profile with strong verbal skills, Williams syndrome does not present with the combination of features described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st   Edition, Chapter – 98 Page No 3024

choices.text: Prader Willi syndrome

questions.text: A mother brought her 5-year-old child with complaints of not being regular to the school as he is gets infections very often. When he attends the school the teacher always complaints about him that he isn’t studying well like his fellow classmates. As you start looking at the child, the child’s face appears to be the same as in the image. On further evaluation the child had notched ears, hypertelorism, thin upper lip, and heart murmurs. You start investigating with blood analysis. RBC and WBC counts were normal and the electrolyte level of serum calcium is found to be 6.5mg/dl. What is the most probable diagnosis based on his clinical features and examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DiGeorge syndrome

 

Option B.

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical features and examination findings is DiGeorge syndrome/ velocardial facial syndrome.

 

  • It is due to microdeletion 22q11.2
  • They have defect in development of 3rd and 4th phalangeal pouch.

 

Clinical symptoms:

  • Thymic aplasia (leads to T cell immunodeficiency à recurrent infection)
  • Parathyroid aplasia/ hypoplasia (leads to low serum calcium <8mg/dl)
  • Cardiovascular defects (conotruncal defect; heart murmurs and blue skin due to low oxygen)
  • Abnormal facies: hypoplasia of auricle, thin upper lip, hypertelorism, low-lying ears.
  • Learning disabilities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Williams syndrome: Known for its "elfin" facial features, cardiovascular disease, and unique cognitive profile, Williams syndrome typically does not present with the immune deficiencies or hypocalcemia that are indicative of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: Also known as trisomy 13, this condition is associated with severe intellectual disability and a range of physical abnormalities, but the specific features and low calcium level described are more characteristic of DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. Prader-Willi syndrome: A genetic disorder characterized by obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism, but not typically associated with the facial features, heart murmurs, or hypocalcemia described in the scenario.

 

Educational objective:

 

DiGeorge syndrome - Congenital heart defect, hypoplasia of parathyroid and thymus, facial and palate anomalies (22q11.2 deletion)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 3031

choices.text: Both a and b

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient department due to concerns about his unusually tall stature and intellectual disability. The pediatrician notes several features suggestive of a genetic condition, including a long face, large ears, and hyperextensible joints. After a thorough examination, the possibility of fragile X syndrome is considered. The doctor explains to the mother that the condition might present more severely in future generations, a phenomenon attributed to the increase in the number of trinucleotide repeats. Which concept is the doctor referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A and B

 

Option A and B.

 

The severity of the disease will increase with further generation because of the increase in the number of Trinucleotide repeats of CGG, this is known as Shermans paradox or phenomenon of Anticipation and is seen in case of fragile x syndrome.

Cause: CGG repeats at FMR1 gene of x chromosome

 

Clinical features:

  • Tall stature
  • Intellectual disability
  • Macro-orchidism (only evident at puberty)
  • Autistic behavior.
  • Hyperextensible joints.
  • Elongated face and chin
  • Large ears.

 

Diagnosis:

 

DNA testing (CGG triplet repeats at FMR1gene with larger than 200 repeats).

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Complete penetrance is seen in case of Autosomal disorders not in case of trinucleotide repeats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anticipation describes the phenomenon where a genetic disorder becomes more severe or has an earlier onset as it is passed down through generations. This is due to the expansion of trinucleotide repeats (in this case, CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene) in each successive generation (a/k/a Sherman's paradox)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 85– Page No 3050

choices.text: Birth weight triples by 1 year
Skin fold thickness is measured in sub scapular region
Weight is measured to the nearest 100 gram
Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length

questions.text: A pediatrician is conducting routine health check-ups in the outpatient department for children of various ages. While performing anthropometric measurements, a newly joined pediatric intern observes the process and later engages in a discussion about the significance and technical aspects of these measurements in assessing child health and nutritional status. The intern makes several statements about common practices in pediatric anthropometry. Which of the following statements made by the intern is NOT true regarding standard anthropometric measurements in pediatrics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Option D.

 

The statement regarding the standing height being approximately 1.7 cm less than the recumbent length is not true. In fact, the recumbent length (measured when a child is lying down) is usually slightly longer than the standing height due to the natural curvature of the spine and compression of intervertebral discs when in an upright position.

 

Standing height is about 0.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Option A, B and C are true regarding the anthropometric measurements.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Birth weight tripling by 1 year of age is a general growth milestone, indicating adequate nutrition and health during the infant's first year.

 

Option B. Skin fold thickness measurements at the subscapular region, along with other sites, are used to estimate body fat composition, which is crucial for assessing nutritional status.

 

Option C. Weighing infants and children to the nearest 100 grams is a standard practice in to ensure accurate monitoring of growth and early detection of any deviations from expected growth patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Length:

 

  • If a child is less than 2 years old, measure recumbent length.
  • If the child is aged 2 years or older and able to stand, measure standing height.
  • In general, standing height is about 0.7 cm less than recumbent length.

 

Points to Remember:

  • Birth weight of Indian children 2.8 Kg.
  • Term neonate regains lost birth weight by 7 to 10 days, preterm by 10 to 14 days
  • Birth weight doubles by 6 months, triples by 1 year, quadruples by 2 years and increases 5 times by 3 years.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic by their mother, who is concerned about the child's noticeably shorter stature compared to peers. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes that the child's short stature appears disproportionate, with a more significant discrepancy between the upper and lower body segments. Considering a potential diagnosis of a condition affecting growth, the pediatrician decides to assess the child's body proportions more closely by measuring the upper segment and lower segment ratios. Understanding the normal progression of body proportions from childhood to adulthood is crucial in this assessment. At what age do the upper and lower segments of the body typically reach adult proportions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 10 years

 

Option D:

 

Upper segment lower segment ratio:

Upper segment — vertex to pubic symphysis

Lower segment — pubic symphysis to heel

 

Normal Values

Birth—1.7:1

3 years—1.3:1

7 years - 1:1

In adults the ratio is: 0.9:1

So, the best answer according to the options is D

 

Explanation:

 

Option A- By the age of 2 years the ratio is 1.4:1

 

Option C- By the age of 7 years the ratio is 1:1 whereas the adult ratio is 0.9:1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper-to-lower body segment ratio (U/L ratio) provides an assessment of truncal growth relative to limb growth. The lower-body segment is defined as the length from the top of the symphysis pubis to the floor, and the upper-body segment is the total height minus the lower-body segment.

The U/L ratio equals approximately 1.7 at birth, 1.3 at 3 year, and 1.0 after 7 year. Higher U/L ratios are characteristic of short-limb dwarfism, as occurs with Turner syndrome or bone disorders, whereas lower ratios suggest hypogonadism or Marfan syndrome.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51; Nelson 21st Ed Pg 1183

choices.text: Child with disease.
Carrier of the disease
Can’t comment at the moment.

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing a 3-month-old child during a routine health maintenance visit. The child appears phenotypically normal without any apparent abnormalities. The mother expresses concern about the child's risk of developing a familial disease that is present in the father's side of the family. She provides a detail indicating the presence of the disease in previous generations. The family Pedigree is given below and the child is marked in the arrow identify the status of the child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carrier of the disease

 

Option C.

 

The marked arrow in the chart is a female with carrier state, since it’s a X linked Recessive disease, it is manifested in males and presents as a carrier in females

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Child with disease is seen in male child of X-linked Recessive disorder, as it is a female child it will be a carrier.

 

Option B. Normal child is not seen in case of X-linked Recessive disorder, males will be affected, and females will be as a carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pedigree symbols and abbreviations –

 

  • Squares represent males, circles represent females and a diamond represents one whose sex is not known.
  • Shaded symbols indicate individuals who are affected by the disease. For >2 conditions the symbols are partitioned correspondingly, each quadrant with different fillings/ patterns representing different features
  • Half-shaded symbols represent carriers of the disease if the condition is autosomal recessive.
  • Unshaded symbols represent individuals who are unaffected and presumably do not carry the disease allele if the condition is autosomal dominant.
  • Symbols with a dot in the center can sometimes represent carriers for X-linked conditions, or less commonly, for autosomal recessive conditions.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition page 11523

choices.text: Poly cystic kidney disease
Overlapping of fingers

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by a mother who is concerned about her child's poor growth and difficulty feeding. The physical examination reveals microcephaly (a small head circumference), a cleft lip and palate, and polydactyly. Based on these findings, the pediatrician considers a diagnosis of Patau Syndrome. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Patau Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Overlapping of fingers

 

Option D.

 

 Overlapping of fingers is a feature of Edward syndrome.

 

 

 

Patau Syndrome

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Holoprosencephaly is a common neurological anomaly in Patau Syndrome, resulting from incomplete brain (MC forebrain) division into right and left hemispheres.  HPE ranges in severity and often causes facial development issues.

 

 

Option B. Cutis Aplasia, a congenital absence of a portion of the skin, is also observed in some cases of Patau Syndrome.

 

 

Option C. Polycystic kidney disease and other renal anomalies can be part of the spectrum of abnormalities seen in Patau Syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Patau Syndrome – Trisomy of 13

Clinical features of Patau Syndrome include,

  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Polydactyly
  • Microcephalus
  • Holoprosencephaly
  • Cutis aplasia
  • Poly cystic kidney disease and
  • Developmental delay

 

Ref: Nelson 21st   Edition, Chapter – 98 Page No 3024

choices.text: Chorionic Villous Sampling
Mothers’ urine examination.

questions.text: A 36 years old pregnant female presents to the Pediatrics department for a regular visit for her 3 years old child with a trisomy which is responsible for the presenile Alzheimer’s disease. You noticed that she is pregnant again and she replied that it is her 2nd pregnancy and she is in her 15th week. As she has the risk of Trisomy again, you advised her to undergo a test for karyotyping. What is the test you advise her considering the gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniocentesis.

 

Option B.

 

Amniocentesis is done between 14th to 16th week, based on the history the child is suffering from Trisomy 21 which is Downs syndrome and is responsible for presenile Alzheimer’s disease, so to diagnose he subsequent case of Trisomy 21 by karyotyping, amniocentesis is done

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cordocentesis is done between 18th to 20th weeks.

 

Option C. Chorionic Villous Sampling is done between 11th to 14th weeks.

 

Option D. Mothers urine examination does not have a significant importance whereas mothers’ blood can be used by the cell free DNA testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-614

choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries.
Endocardial Cushion defects
Pentalogy of Fallot
Coarctation of Aorta

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in by their mother, who is distressed due to criticism from her mother-in-law regarding the child's health. The child has developmental delays, intellectual disability, and distinctive physical features including sandal gap toes. Recently, the child has been diagnosed with a congenital heart disease. Given the child's clinical features, as shown in the images, what is the most common congenital heart disease associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endocardial Cushion defects

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of the child is pointing towards the diagnosis of Downs Syndrome. The most common congenital heart disease in case of Downs syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD)

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are.

Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye.

  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand.
    • Brachycephaly
    • Protrudin  g tongue
    • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease.

 

Option A, C and D aren’t the most common congenital heart disease in Downs Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Downs syndrome - Approximately 40% children have congenital heart disease. Endocardial cushion defects account for about 40-60% cases. Presence of heart disease is the most significant factor in determining survival. All children should have a cardiac evaluation before 9 months of age, including echocardiography.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 610-615.

questions.text: A working mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. On evaluation child is small for her age with a beak-like nose, narrow face, and widely spaced eyes as shown in the image. The mother reports that the child has difficulty feeding due to a small jaw and mouth, and has been slow to reach developmental milestones. The pediatrician diagnoses this as a case of Seckel syndrome. All of the following are features of Seckel syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Macrocephaly

 

Option B.

 

Seckel syndrome is characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal dwarfism, and a unique facial appearance except for macrocephaly, which is not associated with Seckel syndrome and thus is the correct answer.

 

Clinical features of Seckel syndrome include:

  • Microcephaly: a circumference that is below the 3rd percentile for their age and gender.
  • Intellectual disability:
  • Facial abnormalities: Features may include a beak-like nose, narrow face, and Micrognathia. The ears may be low set and rotated backward, and the eyes may be widely spaced and/or have a downward slant.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bones may be thin and/or abnormally shaped, and joints may be hypermobile.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Other features:  heart defects, kidney abnormalities, and seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C and D are the features of Seckel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seckel (SCKL) syndrome, sometimes called “bird-headed dwarfism,” is an autosomal recessive developmental disorder characterized by marked growth failure and mental deficiency, microcephaly, a hypoplastic face with a prominent nose, and low-set and/or malformed ears. Approximately 25% of patients have aplastic anemia or malignancies.

 

Note - There is broad genetic heterogeneity comprising at least 8 classifiable types: SCKL1, ATR mutation; SCKL2, RBBP8 mutation; SCKL3, maps to 14q21-q22; SCKL4, CENPJ mutation; SCKL5, CEP152 mutation; SCKL6, CEP63 mutation; SCKL7, NIN mutation; and SCKL8, ATRIP mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 10133

choices.text: Failure of calcification of cartilage
Failure of membranous ossification
Failure of development of flat bones
Failure of development of long bones

questions.text: A pediatrician in a rural healthcare center is approached by a mother carrying her newborn for an initial health check-up. The infant, as observed in the image provided, exhibits significant limb abnormalities. The mother reports that during her pregnancy, she had taken medication from a local healer, which you suspect may have contained Thalidomide due to the timing and nature of the birth defects. Considering the history of maternal medication intake and the clinical presentation of the infant, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Failure of development of long bones

 

Explanation:

 

Phocomelia refers to Failure of development of long bones.

Phocomelia Syndrome (PS)

 

  • Rare birth defects that cause severe birth defects, especially of the upper limbs.
  • The bones of the arms may be extremely shortened and even absent. The fingers of the hands may be fused.
    • Risk factors:
    • Maternal thalidomide therapy.
    • Genetic inheritance.
    • Roberts’s syndrome.
  • An extreme case results in the absence of the upper bones of both the arms and legs so that the hands and feet appear attached directly to the body. This is called tetraphocomelia
  • Other associated anomalies:
    • Encephalocele.
    • Hydrocephalus.
    • Bicornuate uterus.
    • Short neck.
    • Thrombocytopenia.
    • Renal and cardiac anomalies.

 

Other 3 options are incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phocomelia Syndrome is a rare birth defect characterized by underdeveloped long bones, often related to maternal thalidomide exposure, leading to shortened or absent limbs and potentially associated with other anomalies like Encephalocele, Hydrocephalus, Bicornuate uterus, Short neck, thrombocytopenia, renal and cardiac anomalies.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1698

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by his mother due to concerns about his unusual height; he is taller than his classmates and even his class teacher. Further evaluation reveals language defects, learning disabilities, and decreased IQ. Physical examination notes significant gynecomastia (large breasts), delayed secondary sexual characteristics, and small testes. Based on the clinical history, what is the most probable diagnosis, and what karyotype is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klinefelter syndrome and 47 XXY

 

Option C.

 

The clinical features of the 15-year-old boy is suggestive of Klinefelter syndrome.

They are phenotypically male, it is MCC of infertility and hypogonadism in males and mc sex chromosome aneuploidy in humans. Karyotype-47xxy.

Cause: Nondisjunction of paternal meiosis 2.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Tall stature

  • Testes and penis are small

  • Gynecomastia

  • Delayed secondary sexual character. (puberty occurs at normal age)

  • Low IQ, behavioural problems, learning disability, psychosocial.

 

Management:

 

Psychosocial and behavioural rehabilitation.

Testosterone should be started at middle to late adolescent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fragile x syndrome is seen as a result of trinucleotide repeats (mutations in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome) and they will have normal karyotype with features of low IQ, long face, larger ears and gonads.

 

Option B. In case of Klinefelter syndrome the abnormality of karyotype seen is 47XXY not the 45 XO karyotype. 45,XO karyotype is associated with Turner syndrome

 

Option D. Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by tall stature, long limbs, and cardiovascular abnormalities, but it does not typically include the cognitive or gonadal features seen in Klinefelter syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome in males, leading to a 47,XXY karyotype. This genetic anomaly results in a phenotype that includes taller than average height, gynecomastia, small testes, delayed or absent secondary sexual characteristics, and often language and learning difficulties.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 601 Page No 117161-1721

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric outpatient department by her mother due to concerns about her short stature. During the evaluation, the physician notes several distinctive features: a webbed neck, a low posterior hairline, and a dislocated patella. Given the clinical presentation suggestive of a genetic anomaly, karyotyping is performed, and the findings are shown in the accompanying image. Based on the history and karyotyping results, what is the most probable diagnosis, and what management options should be considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome; reassurance

 

Option B.

 

As its a case of Turners syndrome laparoscopic gonadectomy is recommended for the increased risk of gonadoblastoma  in cases of 45 XO/46 XY due to presence of Y chromosome has increased risk of gonadoblastoma.

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features-

  • Short stature

  • Shield chest

  • Webbed neck

  • Wide spread nipples and

  • Short fourth metacarpal

 

Associated anomalies-

  • CVS : coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve

  • Renal: horse shoe kidney.

  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.

  • Strabismus

  • Cataract.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.

  • Karyotype is indicated in all turner syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with gonadoblastoma).

  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.

  • Managements:

  • GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

  • Patients with Y chromosome mosaicism laparoscopic gonadectomy is recommended.

 

Note: phenotypic females with 45XO/46XY mosaicism have 15-30% risk of developing gonadoblastoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A and Option C. Klinefelter syndrome is seen in boys with karyotype 47XXY and they will have tall stature instead of short stature in turners syndrome.

 

Option D.  Laparoscopic gonadectomy in cases of 45 XO/46 XY due to presence of Y chromosome has increased risk of gonadoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome and the absence of all or part of a second sex chromosome in females, leading to various clinical manifestations, including short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, and potential skeletal abnormalities such as a dislocated patella.

 

The recommendation for laparoscopic gonadectomy in Turner syndrome is specific to patients who have Y chromosome material, as they are at an increased risk for gonadoblastoma, a type of tumor that can develop in the dysgenetic gonads. Gonadectomy is an important preventive measure.

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition Page No-536-537

choices.text: Marfan syndrome and Autosomal Dominant
Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Autosomal Dominant
Marfan syndrome and Autosomal Recessive
Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Autosomal Recessive

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of frequent joint pain, easy bruising, and hypermobility. While explaining she reports she has some magical skills and she can stretch her skin easily and that she has had several episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. As she was accompanied by her father you ask for the family history, he admits the same that he has also experienced the same and he is being treated by the physiotherapist, What is the diagnosis based her clinical features and family history, what is the mode of inheritance in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Autosomal Dominant.

 

Option B.

 

Ehlers Danlos Syndrome is an autosomal Dominant disease caused by genetic mutations in the COL3A1 gene resulting in excessive connective tissue fragility causing arterial, uterine, and intestinal ruptures and premature death.

 

Clinical features.

  • Joint hypermobility
  • Skin hyperextensibility
  • Fragile skin
  • Easy bruising
  • Chronic pain
  • Gastrointestinal abnormalities
  • Cardiovascular abnormalities
  • Dental abnormalities
  • Visual abnormalities.

There are different types of EDS based on the type, the clinical features may vary based on the type of Ehlers Danlos Syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Marfan syndrome and Autosomal Dominant - Marfan syndrome is associated with connective tissue abnormalities and is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but it is typically characterized by tall stature, long extremities, and cardiovascular anomalies, not the skin and joint manifestations described.

 

Option C. Marfan syndrome and Autosomal Recessive – Incorrect.

 

Option D. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome and Autosomal Recessive - Incorrect. Ehlers Danlos Syndrome is an Autosomal Dominant inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features of joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, easy bruising, and a positive family history suggest a diagnosis of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS). EDS is a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by varying degrees of skin, joint, and blood vessel involvement. The most common type of EDS is the hypermobility type, which is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. This means that only one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 618-619 and 644-645.

questions.text: While shadowing a pediatric consultant in the outpatient department (OPD), you observe him palpating the head of a young child during the examination. After the clinic session, you inquire with a junior resident (JR) about the examination technique. The JR explains that the consultant was assessing the closure of the child's fontanelles. Prompted by this discussion, the JR quizzes you on your knowledge of fontanelle closure. Which fontanelle is typically the last to close in a child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior

 

Option A.

 

In humans, the sequence of fontanelle closure is as follows:

 

  • Posterior fontanelle normally closes 2-3 months after birth
  • Sphenoidal fontanelle is the next to close around 6 months after birth
  • Mastoid fontanelle closes next from 6-18 months after birth.
  • The anterior fontanelle is generally the last to close between 1-3 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sphenoidal fontanelle closes by 6 months after birth.

 

Option C. Mastoid fontanelle closes by 6-18 months after birth.

 

Option D. Posterior fontanelle closes by 2-3 months after birth.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 03

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-months-old child to the clinic with a history of developmental delays, Failure to thrive, and anomaly shown in the image. On further evaluation he has a small head circumference, low-set ears, small mouth and clenched hands with overlapping fingers. Additional findings of heart murmur and scoliosis were also noted. The physician suspects it to be case of Trisomy based on the clinical findings, What is the Karyotype finding is seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trisomy 18 (Edward Syndrome)
 

Option A.

 

It is the 2nd most common autosomal trisomy

Clinical features includes -

  • Rocker bottom feet
  • Overlapping fingers
  • Clenched fist
  • Short sternum
  • Hypoplastic nails
  • Hypoplastic nasal alae
  • IUGR
  • Intellectual disability
  • Microcephaly
  • Hypertonia
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Limited hip abduction
  • Cleft lip / palate

 

Most common cardiac defect

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • PDA

 

Most common cause of death- Central apnea.

Prenatal screen lab findings

  • Low fetoprotein
  • Low estriol
  • Low hCG

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome) - This condition typically presents with distinct facial features, a single palmar crease, hypotonia, and intellectual disability, which do not completely match the features described in the question.

 

Option C. Trisomy 18 (Patau Syndrome) - This is an incorrect combination of the syndrome's name and trisomy number; Trisomy 18 is Edward Syndrome, not Patau Syndrome.

 

Option D. Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome) - While Trisomy 13, or Patau Syndrome, also presents with severe congenital anomalies, the specific features mentioned in the scenario are more characteristic of Trisomy 18.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st   Edition, Chapter – 98 Page No 3024

choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries.
Tetralogy of Fallot.
Pentalogy of Fallot.
Coarctation of Aorta.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's emotional well-being following incidents of bullying at school. The mother reports that her daughter has been ridiculed for her lack of secondary sexual characteristics and absence of menarche. After a thorough history and physical examination, the pediatrician orders an ultrasound, which reveals an infantile uterus and streak ovaries. Further genetic workup indicates a ring chromosome abnormality involving one of the X chromosomes. The pediatrician begins a discussion about starting hormonal therapy to induce secondary sexual characteristic development. During the consultation, the mother inquires about any associated cardiac anomalies that might be present with her daughter's condition. As a pediatrician, which cardiac anomaly would you inform the mother is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coarctation of Aorta.

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis based on the history and the Image given is the Turners Syndrome.

In Turners Syndrome CVS abnormalities like coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve can be seen.

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features-

  • Short stature
  • Shield chest
  • Webbed neck
  • Wide spread nipples and
  • Short fourth metacarpal

 

 

Associated anomalies-

  • CVS: coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Renal: horseshoe kidney.
  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.
  • Strabismus
  • Cataract.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.
  • Karyotype is indicated in all turner syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with gonadoblastoma).
  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.
  • Managements:
  • GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

 

Option A, B and C are not the most common CVS abnormality in case of Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45, X karyotype) or a structural abnormality of one of the X chromosomes, such as a ring chromosome. Coarctation of the aorta is a common cardiac anomaly associated with Turner syndrome, occurring in approximately 10-20% of individuals with the condition. It involves a narrowing of the aorta, which can lead to hypertension and an increased workload on the left ventricle.

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9Th Edition – Page No-637

choices.text: Serum calcium 6.5 mg/dl
Normal Serum calcium
No significance of Serum calcium

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric department by her mother due to concerns about constipation, easy fatigability, muscle soreness, and weakness. The mother also expresses frustration with her daughter's academic performance, noting that she does not study as well as her brother. The pediatrician observes that the child has a very friendly personality and a broad forehead. Initial blood tests, including a complete blood count, do not reveal any significant abnormalities. Suspecting Williams syndrome, the pediatrician decides to check the serum calcium levels. What would be the expected serum calcium level in a case of Williams syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum calcium >11mg/dl

 

Explanation:

 

In case of William syndrome there will be increased Serum calcium.

William syndrome (deletion of chromosome 7q11.23)

 

 

Clinical features:

  • Round face with full cheeks, wide mouth, epicanthal fold, upturned nose, large ears, small jaw
  • Intellectual disability
  • Friendly personality
  • Broad forehead

 

Associated features:

 

Hypercalcemia > 11mg/dl (leads to constipation, muscle weakness, lethargy, depression etc)

 

CVS: supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

Note - Serum calcium 6.5 mg/dl is more commonly seen in Digeorge syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

William syndrome – Hypercalcemia, supravalvular aortic stenosis, abnormal facies (7q11.23 deletion)

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 4242.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath and fainting episode. On further evaluation features of short stature and webbed neck were noted. He was subjected to cardiological examination where he is diagnosed with pulmonary stenosis. A genetic testing was done in which chromosome 12 is found to be abnormal. On compiling all the history and clinical features he is diagnosed as a case of pseudo turner syndrome known as Noonan Syndrome. What is the gene responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTPN 11 gene

 

Option B.

 

PTPN 11 gene in chromosome 12 is responsible for Noonan Syndrome

 

Clinical features include;

  • Short stature
  • webbed neck
  • Anti-mongoloid Slant of eyes.

Most common cardiac anomaly associated is Pulmonary stenosis 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CLCN 7 gene mutation will results in osteopetrosis, a condition characterized by increased bone density and abnormal bone growth.

 

Option C. CFTR gene mutation will result in Cystic Fibrosis, affecting the lungs, pancreas, and other organs.

 

Option D. ATM gene mutation will results in Ataxia Telangiectasia, rare inherited childhood neurological disorder that affects the part of the brain that controls motor movement (intended movement of muscles) and speech. The triad of symptoms includes progressive ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasias and sinopulmonary disease. 

 

Educational objective:

 

Turner Syndrome vs Noonan Syndrome

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 601– Page No 11714-11716

choices.text: Prader Willi syndrome
Di George syndrome

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 5-year-old girl child to the pediatric OPD with complaints of her constant feeling of hunger. Her mother mentions that she is obese than everyone in her class. On evaluation she has a short stature, intellectual disability and the following appearance. While asking her history in the past, her mother reminded that she had a feeding difficulty at birth as she was hypotonic and she had this voracious appetite from age of 2. Her mother was concerned about her future and asks you to diagnose her. What is the most probable diagnosis you will make and convey to her mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prader Willi syndrome

 

Option B.

 

The diagnosis based on the clinical feature and the image is Prader Willi syndrome.

Genomic Imprinting:15q11-microdeletion of paternal side or inheritance of both copies from maternal side.

Clinical features:

  • Short stature (responsive to growth hormone)
  • Intellectually disability
  • Hypotonia
  • Small hand and feet
  • Obesity
  • Hyperphagia (ghrelin increased).
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Angelman syndrome: Characterized by severe intellectual disability, lack of speech, seizures, and a happy demeanor, but not typically associated with obesity or the described feeding pattern.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: Associated with congenital heart defects, immune deficiencies, and cleft palate, among other symptoms, but not typically presenting with obesity and excessive hunger.

 

Option D. Williams syndrome: Known for hypercalcemia, cardiovascular issues, unique cognitive profile, and very social personality, Williams syndrome does not typically involve the described pattern of early-life feeding difficulties followed by excessive appetite and obesity.

 

Educational objective:

 

The history of hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by excessive appetite and obesity, alongside intellectual challenges (mental retardation), hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, aligns with Prader-Willi syndrome. (15q11 deletion)

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 625, 3058

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought in by their mother for a routine pediatric evaluation. The child appears alert and active, and according to the mother, the infant has been gaining weight and height steadily since birth. The pediatrician proceeds with a thorough physical examination and notes the following finding. The pediatrician considers various differential diagnoses for this finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this clinical feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MPS

 

Option C.

The given image is suggestive of microcephaly, it is not seen in case of MPS (Mucopolysaccharidoses). MPS typically presents with various skeletal abnormalities and may not necessarily involve microcephaly, making it the least likely cause of the finding in this scenario compared to the other options listed.

 

Microcephaly Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference more than 2 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for given age, sex and gestation.

 

Option A, B and D are the causes of microcephaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. PKU - Infants with PKU can present with microcephaly if the condition is untreated due to the toxic effects of elevated phenylalanine levels on brain development.

 

Option B. Down's syndrome - Children with Down's syndrome often have brachycephaly, which may give the appearance of a smaller head circumference and can sometimes be associated with actual microcephaly.

 

Option D. Fetal Hydantoin syndrome - This syndrome can result from exposure to antiepileptic drugs in utero and is associated with a range of congenital defects, including microcephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of Microcephaly

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 40.
